creator: reetz@usco.de
text:
This JSP code includes a JPG file of 3898 bytes, the browser displays a scrambled picture and with a lan analyzer I found that there were sent back 3899 
bytes content. Getting the test2.jpg file directly resulted in no error.
I have seen this under Linux with the IBM JDK 1.3 and under NetWare with JVM 1.3.

<%@ page language="java"%><%
response.setContentType("image/jpeg");
response.setContentLength(3898);
%><%@include file="test2.jpg"%>


Regards

Egon Reetz

creator: nacho@apache.org
text:
Can you test this behaviour with TC 3.1.1 or better Tc 3.2.2 of 3.3..

Thanks..

Better for component Servlet..

Please to correctly fill a bug report is important to help us, and the possible 
fixer.. Please fill in the gaps.. ( Plataform, OS, etc..) thanks
creator: nacho@apache.org

text:
Tested with TC 3.3-m4, results are the same.
Additionally I made a compare between the original jpg file and the wrong one.
What I see is:
0x0D is deleted from output
0x0A inserts 0x0D 0x0D (and 0x0A)into output
creator: reetz@usco.de
Larry.Isaacs@sas.com
text:
The "<%@include %>" directive is a translation time include, which means that
the JSP engine is going to parse the resource.  If that resource is a binary
file, the results will be unpredictable.  If the file contained the two byte
sequence for "<%", then the response would likely be JSP syntax error.
